content.description:
Nice warmup on the Royal Flush cluster.

Layback the short flake to a jug and the strange fin feature above -- but don't pull it off
content.protection: 1 pad should be sufficient landing is pretty flat and the climb is very vertical
content.location: South facing wall of boulder adjacent to Royal Flush (i.e. same boulder as Lead Pants)

content.description: Start to the left of Royal Flush on low jugs.  Campus or use fancy footwork trending up and right. Pull over the lip to positive, but less juggy holds.
content.location: About 10ft left of the Royal Flush hand crack.

content.description: Not sure why no one has added this yet.  Start sitting in the cave under the RF boulder on a horizontal finger crack slot. Work your way out of the cave and over the lip.  A key right foot and left hand will get you up to the top out.  Very fun!
content.protection: 2-3 pads, no need for a spotter.
content.location: The problem, and a few others, is found on the side of the Royal Flush boulder as its namesake.  You can climb under the entire boulder from Royal Flush to find this problem.

content.description: The obvious and famous roof crack on the namesake boulder.  If your technique is not flawless you will want to tape.  The crux may depend on your hand size but turning the lip is no gimmie.

Start matched in pod above the small boulder and traverse left to follow decent holds up the arete.

V0 variation: start at large jug at arete, head straight up via long move to chunky edge.
content.protection: preferably two pads, 1 for rock under start and one for topout

content.description: Sit start with a good sloper left hand and a terrible sloping undercling right hand. Do some fancy footwork, hit the sloping, then finish straight up with another sloper and nice jug. Hardest part is getting off the ground, but once you figure it out, it's easy. Awesome for a 3 move problem.
content.location: Behind the Royal Flush boulder, there is a short boulder with a couple easy warm-up problems on it. Lead Pants is the problem closest to Royal Flush

content.description:
Start with the lowest left hand sloper on the left and a lower right hand crimp/edge. Stick a foot in the crack, then move up and right using a decent sloper and some edges.

This is listed as a V6 in the guidebook. Most people seem to think that's spot on, but I think it's very soft.
content.protection: 3 pads or more to cover everything.
content.location: To the right of the Royal Flush crack.

content.description:
[GUIDEBOOK VAR] Originally a one move power test somewhere around V9. This variation uses a low foot smear at the start. Stab from the pinches to the lip, try not to dab, and mantle over.

[HEEL HOOK VAR] Start with a heel hook and two overhanging pinches. Reach to the lip and mantle over. Easier and less contrived, different. Probably a V2 this way.
content.location: Look for two overhanging pinches to the left of the crack on the south facing side of the Royal Flush boulder. Directly to the left of Sitting Bull.

content.description: Begin on “royal flush’ deep under in the cave on the horizontal hand crack in the ceiling. Jam out until you hit the 45 degree section and set up for a wide move right to good side pulls. Compress slopers on the left with good edges on the right. Positive crimps lead over the top.
content.protection: Pads for the roof crack and the stepped rocky landing.
content.location: Starts on “royal flush’ on the lowest part of the hand crack in the ceiling of the cave. Moves into ‘jack of spades’
